Project Preparatory Technical Assistance 
 
Project Number: 45044

Socialist Republic of Viet Nam: Improvement of 
Road Safety and Climate Resilience on National 
Highways

PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The  project  will  cover  improvement  of  traffic  safety  and  climate  resilience  for 
approximately 180 kilometer (km) of NH 1 in Ninh Thuan and Binh Thuan provinces.1 The 
primary necessity for the PPTA is to assist the Government by providing a systematic and 
coordinated approach to (i) identify critical subproject traffic safety “black spots” and segments 
with high climate change risks; (ii) engineer solutions, and provide a set of detailed design 
guidelines  to  remedy  the  problems;  (iii)  develop  capacity  enhancement  and  other  non-
infrastructure solutions; and (iv) prioritize subprojects for implementation under the project loan. 
 
2.  The infrastructure solutions are expected to encompass a wide range of relatively large, 
mid-size and a number of small civil works and equipment subprojects covering such items as (i) 
replacing, upgrading and widening narrow unsafe bridges2; (ii) improving the safety and capacity 
of  at-grade  intersections;  (iii)  eliminating  dangerous  “black  spots”  by  improving  roadway 
geometry  and  facility  (crash  barriers,  crash  cushions,  bus  bays,  semi-automatic  traffic 
surveillance and information system, etc.) and increasing driver’s sight distances and visibility 
(e.g. light-emitting delineator); (iv) introducing improved slope protection measures in areas of 
land and rock slides; (v) raising/reconstructing of highway embankments and bridges along 
sections prone to dangerous flooding; (vi) increasing cross-drainage capacity; (vii) providing a 
separated  motorcycle  lane  along  areas  of  high  traffic  density  with  a  history  of  accidents 
involving  motorcycles,  bicycles  and  pedestrians;  (viii)  providing  pedestrian  bridges,  traffic 
signals, signage, pavement markings and similar improvements to increase traffic safety; and (ix) 
reconstruction of roadways and bridges along selected sections of the highway that are prone to 
severe and repeated flooding. 
 
3.  Initial  investigations  by  the  Government  indicate  that  the  approximate  cost  of 
implementing the improvements of the major traffic safety corrective measures and reducing 
roadway flooding is in excess of $200 million. This PPTA will refine these costs, establish 
priorities, and provide detailed engineering solutions for incorporation in the detailed designs to 
be prepared by detailed design consultants. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
4.  The major outputs of the PPTA include a detailed feasibility study that prioritizes traffic 
safety improvements and reduces roadway flooding and other climate change risks along one of 
the most heavily traveled sections of NH1; capacity enhancement of relevant staff in the Traffic 
Safety Project Management Unit (TSPMU), Directorate of Roads for Viet Nam (DRVN), and 
Provincial Traffic Safety Committees in traffic safety and climate adaptation of coastal roads; 
and developing appropriate methodology and conducting seminars to assist in the design for a 
traffic safety campaign to be carried out during loan implementation. Major activities include: (i) 
review of current situations on traffic safety and climate change adaptation by the government 
and development partners including the International Road Assessment Programme (iRAP); (ii)

feasibility study and design of the ADB’s ensuing loan project and processing support; and (iii) 
capacity  assessment  and  enhancement  of  TSPMU,  DRVN,  and  Provincial  Traffic  Safety 
Committees.3

D.  Consulting Services

international experts and 79 person-months of national experts will be required. The consulting 
firm will be selected by quality- and cost-based selection using the quality–cost ratio of 90:10 
and full technical proposals in accordance with ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants, April 
2010.

8.  The outline terms of reference for the required personnel are as following. The team 
leader  shall  have  a  strong  background  in  project  management,  highway  engineering,  with 
pertinent experience in conducting road safety audits, traffic engineering and feasibility studies. 
Transport economists in addition to typical experience in highway transport economics, shall 
have the ability to develop unique routines to determine economic benefits based on improved 
traffic  safety.  Bridge  engineering  specialists  shall  have  experience  in  bridge  condition 
investigations, and experience in estimating bridge load carrying capacity and remaining bridge 
service life. Hydrology specialists shall be pertinent experience in the estimation of flood flows in 
tropical  regions.  Safeguard  and  gender  specialists  shall  have  a  strong  background  in 
applications of ADB policies and guidelines, or those of similar internationally accepted entities. 
The traffic safety campaign and capacity development specialist shall have pertinent experience 
in the design and carrying out of traffic safety campaigns and institutional capacity development, 
particularly in the developing world. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
9.  The executing agency will be the Ministry of Transport (MOT). DRVN and its relevant 
Regional  Management  Units  will  support  by  providing  data  on  road  conditions  and 
accident/flooding  records.  The  implementing  agency  will  be  TSPMU.  The  Government  is 
expected to authorize the MOT as the line ministry and the TSPMU as the project owner in the 
project detailed outline. Disbursements under the PPTA will be done in accordance with the 
ADB’s TA Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time).
